A Hybrid Architecture for
Federated and Centralized Learning

Abstract

Many of the machine learning tasks rely on centralized learning (CL), which requires the transmission of local datasets from the clients to a parameter server (PS) entailing huge communication overhead. To overcome this, federated learning (FL) has been suggested as a promising tool, wherein the clients send only the model updates to the PS instead of the whole dataset. However, FL demands powerful computational resources from the clients. In practice, not all the clients have sufficient computational resources to participate in training. To address this common scenario, we propose a more efficient approach called hybrid federated and centralized learning (HFCL), wherein only the clients with sufficient resources employ FL, while the remaining ones send their datasets to the PS, which computes the model on behalf of them. Then, the model parameters are aggregated at the PS. To improve the efficiency of dataset transmission, we propose two different techniques: i) increased computation-per-client and ii) sequential data transmission. Notably, the HFCL frameworks outperform FL with up to 20%percent2020\% improvement in the learning accuracy when only half of the clients perform FL while having 50%percent5050\% less communication overhead than CL since all the clients collaborate on the learning process with their datasets.

Index Terms:
Machine learning, federated learning, centralized learning, edge intelligence, edge efficiency.

I Introduction

The ever growing increase in the number of connected devices in the last few years has led to a surge in the amount of data generated by mobile phones, connected vehicles, drones and internet of things (IoT) devices due to the rapid development of various emerging applications, such as artificial intelligence (AI), virtual and augmented reality (VAR), autonomous vehicles (AVs), and machine-to-machine communicationsÂ [2, 3]. According to international telecommunication union (ITU), the global mobile traffic is expected to reach 607607607 EB by 2025. Moreover, AVs are expected to generate approximately 20 TB/day/vehicleÂ [4]. In order to process and extract useful information from the huge amount of data, machine learning (ML) has been recognized as a promising tool for emerging technologies, such as IoTÂ [5], AVÂ [6], and next generation wireless communicationsÂ [7, 8, 9] due to its success in image/speech recognition, natural language processing, etcÂ [2]. These applications require huge amount of data to be processed and learned by a learning model, often an artificial neural network (ANN), by extracting the features from the raw data and providing a â€œmeaningâ€ to the input via constructing a model-free data mapping with huge number of learnable parametersÂ [7]. The implementation of these learning models demands powerful computation resources, such as graphics processing units (GPUs). Therefore, huge learning models, massive amount of training data, and powerful computation infrastructure are the main driving factors defining the success of ML algorithmsÂ [7, 3].

Many of the ML tasks are based on centralized learning (CL) algorithms, which train powerful ANNs at a parameter server (PS)Â [2, 10, 11]. While CL inherently assumes the availability of datasets at the PS, this may not be possible for the wireless edge devices (clients), such as mobile phones, connected vehicles, and IoT devices, which need to send their datasets to the PS. Transmitting the collected datasets to the PS in a reliable manner may be too costly in terms of energy, latency, and bandwidthÂ [12]. For example, in LTE (long term evolution), a single frame of 555 MHz bandwidth and 101010 ms duration can carry only 600060006000 complex symbolsÂ [13], whereas the size of the whole dataset can be on the order of hundreds of thousands symbolsÂ [14]. As a result, CL-based techniques require huge bandwidth and communication overhead during training.

In order to provide a practically viable alternative to CL-based training, federated learning (FL) has been proposed to exploit the processing capability of the edge devices and the local datasets of the clientsÂ [11, 15, 16]. In FL, the clients compute and transmit the model parameters to the PS instead of their local datasets as in CL to collaboratively train the learning model. The collected model updates are aggregated at the PS and then broadcast to the clients to further update the learning parameters iteratively. Since FL does not access the whole dataset at once, it has slightly lower learning performance than that of CL. However, FL is communication-efficient and privacy-preserving since it keeps the datasets at the clients. Recently, FL has been applied to image classificationÂ [15, 12, 17], speech recognitionÂ [18] and wireless communicationsÂ [19, 20]. In particular, various wireless network architectures exploiting FL have been investigated, such as cellular networksÂ [21, 22, 13], vehicular networksÂ [6], unmanned aerial vehiclesÂ [23], IoT networksÂ [24], and for the design of physical layer applicationsÂ [25]. In these works, the FL architectures rely on the fact that all of the clients are capable of model computation, which may require powerful parallel processing units, such as GPUs. However, this may not always be possible in practice due to the diversity of the devices with different computation capabilities, such as mobile phones, vehicular components and IoT devices. When the edge devices lack of sufficient computational power, they cannot perform model computation, and thus become unable to participate in the learning process. To address this problem, client selection algorithms have been developed. InÂ [26] and [27], trusted clients and the ones with sufficient computational resources are participated in FL-based training. However, these studies do not allow the clients that are not selected to participate in the training process, regardless of their computational capability.

In this work, we introduce a hybrid FL and CL (HFCL) framework for which the main motivation is to effectively train a learning model regardless of the computational capability of the clients. By exploiting their computational resources, the clients that are capable of model computation perform FL while the remaining clients resort to CL and send their datasets to the PS, which computes the corresponding model parameters on behalf of them (see Fig.Â 1). At the beginning of the training, the clients are designated as inactive (i.e., CL is applied) or active (i.e., FL is employed) depending on their computational capabilities. That is, the clients are called active if they have adequate computational resources, e.g., GPUs, to compute the model parameters, whereas the clients are called inactive otherwise in such a case, hence they send their datasets to the PS, which computes the model parameters on behalf of them. The PS, then, optimizes the bandwidth allocation by minimizing the maximum communication delay of the clients. During model training, both active and inactive clients are synchronized and the training process is conducted iteratively as in FL, where the model parameters are aggregated in each communication round between the PS and the active clients. Prior to the model training, the inactive clients transmit the datasets to the PS so that the PS can compute model updates on behalf of them during training. In the meantime, the active clients perform model computation. Once the model parameters corresponding to active (computed on device) and inactive (computed on PS) clients are collected at the PS, they are aggregated and broadcast to the active clients only so that they can compute the model parameters in the next iteration. Since the PS computes the model parameters on behalf of the inactive clients, it is not necessary to broadcast model updates to them. As a result, the proposed HFCL approach provides a trade-off among learning performance, communication overhead, privacy, and the clientsâ€™ computational resources (see, e.g., TableÂ I). While the usage of CL enables higher learning performance and lower dependence on the clientsâ€™ computational resources, FL enjoys enhanced privacy and less communication overhead. In contrast, HFCL jointly employs CL and FL. Therefore, it enjoys less communication overhead than CL; higher performance and more flexibility than FL, while it is less privacy-preserving and lower communication-efficient than FL. Thus, HFCL can be particularly useful when the dataset does not include privacy-sensitive content, e.g., physical layer dataÂ [25].

Although the integration of FL and CL may seem straightforward, there are two main challenges in HFCL. First, training time of HFCL is longer than FL since the inactive clients need to transmit their datasets to the PS prior to the training. In other words, the active clients should wait for the inactive clients at the beginning of the training until the dataset transmission for inactive clients is completed so that they can synchronously participate in model training. To circumvent this problem and provide efficient model training, we propose sequential dataset transmission (HFCL-SDT) where the inactive clientsâ€™ datasets are divided into smaller blocks to complete the dataset transmission quicker. Second, the learning accuracy of HFCL is lower than CL since the model parameters corresponding to the active clients are noisy due to wireless transmission. To improve the learning accuracy, we propose increased computation-per-client (HFCL-ICpC) approach where the training continues at the active clients during the transmission of inactive clientsâ€™ datasets instead of waiting idle for the inactive clients as in basic HFCL, in which the active clients wait for the completion of dataset transmission. Thus, HFCL-ICpC improves the learning performance as compared to HFCL without increasing the delay due to dataset generation. In summary, HFCL-ICpC improves the learning performance while HFCL-SDT reduces the dataset transmission time per communication round. Inspired fromÂ [15], where the model parameters are infrequently aggregated at the clients, we develop a new approach to first aggregate the model parameters at the clients until the transmission of the inactive clientsâ€™ datasets is completed, then continue aggregating the models at the PS. Compared toÂ [15], our technique achieves a better learning performance as well as flexibility on the hardware requirements since the learning model can be trained on the whole dataset even if a part of the clients do not have computational resources. Compared to our preliminary workÂ [1], this paper introduces HFCL-ICpC approach to improve learning accuracy, theoretical analysis on the convergence of HFCL, and the implementation of the 3-D object detection scenario. While the term hybrid is used in some recent FL-based works in terms of client schedulingÂ [28], data partitioningÂ [29] and data securityÂ [30], this is the first work employing a hybrid architecture of FL and CL by exploiting the hardware capability of the edge devices. The main contributions of this paper are as follows:

  • â€¢

    We propose a hybrid FL/CL approach to manage the diverse computational capabilities of the edge clients. In the proposed approach, only the clients, which have adequate computational resources perform FL while the remaining clients perform CL.

  • â€¢

    We show that the performance of HFCL converges to that of FL (CL) when the number of active clients increases (decreases). Specifically when the active and inactive clients are partitioned equally, the proposed HFCL approach exhibits up to 20%percent2020\% improvement in the learning accuracy compared to FL. HFCL also enjoys 50%percent5050\% less communication overhead with only 2%percent22\% loss in the learning accuracy as compared to CL.

  • â€¢

    To efficiently transmit the datasets of the inactive clients to the PS, we propose the HFCL-SDT and HFCL-ICpC techniques to achieve no interruption of the learning process. Compared to FL, the proposed techniques are effective due to faster convergence rates and higher learning accuracy together with less communication delay due to less dataset transmission.

In SectionÂ VI, we investigate the convergence and the communication overhead of the HFCL approach. III Hybrid Federated and Centralized Learning

In this section, we introduce the proposed HFCL framework by taking into account the computational capability of the clients so that all clients can contribute to the learning task with their datasets regardless of their ability to compute the model parameters. The motivation is based on the following inadequacy observed in practice. In ML tasks, training a model requires huge computational power to compute the model parameters. This requirement cannot always be satisfied by the computational capabilities of the client devices. For this reason, an effective training of the ML model, we propose a hybrid training framework that accounts for the computational capabilities of the clients. Specifically, we assume that only a portion of the clients with sufficient computational power performs FL, while the remaining clients, which suffer from inadequate computational capability, send their datasets to the PS for model computation, as illustrated in Fig.Â 1c.

Let us define the set of clients who perform CL, i.e., sending datasets to the PS, and the ones who perform FL, i.e., transmitting the model parameters to the PS as â„’={1,â€¦,L}â„’1â€¦ğ¿\mathcal{L}=\{1,\dots,L\} and â„’Â¯={L+1,â€¦,K}Â¯â„’ğ¿1â€¦ğ¾\bar{\mathcal{L}}=\{L+1,\dots,K\}, respectively, where ğ’¦=â„’â€‹â‹ƒâ„’Â¯ğ’¦â„’Â¯â„’\mathcal{K}=\mathcal{L}\bigcup\bar{\mathcal{L}} and â„’âˆ©â„’Â¯=âˆ…â„’Â¯â„’\mathcal{L}\cap\bar{\mathcal{L}}=\emptyset. Furthermore, we refer to the clients in â„’â„’\mathcal{L} and â„’Â¯Â¯â„’\bar{\mathcal{L}} as inactive and active clients, respectively. The determination of clientâ€™s condition (i.e., active/inactive) can be done by the devices sending information on their computational resources to the PSÂ [26, 27]. By exploiting the availability of computational resources of the clients, the HFCL problem can be formulated as optimization of model parameters at the client and PS as follows

PS::PSabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{PS:}\hskip 10.0pt ğœ½k=argâ¡minğœ½â¡â„±kâ€‹(ğœ½),kâˆˆâ„’,formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ½ğ‘˜subscriptğœ½subscriptâ„±ğ‘˜ğœ½ğ‘˜â„’\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),\hskip 10.0ptk\in\mathcal{L}, (7b)
PS::PSabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{PS:}\hskip 10.0pt ğœ½=âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦Dkâ€‹ğœ½kD,ğœ½subscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğ·ğ‘˜subscriptğœ½ğ‘˜ğ·\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}=\frac{\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}D_{k}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}{D}, (7c)

where the PS actively participates in the model computation process and computes ğœ½ksubscriptğœ½ğ‘˜\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} for kâˆˆâ„’ğ‘˜â„’k\in\mathcal{L} since the inactive clients do not have sufficient computational capabilities. Once the model parameters are computed, the PS aggregates them as in (7c).

III-A Noisy Learning Model

In HFCL, both the model parameters and the datasets are corrupted by noise due to wireless linksÂ [31, 20]. Compared to the noise in the datasets (for image classification, see SectionÂ VII), the effect of noisy model parameters is significant since it directly corrupts the learning modelÂ [1]. During model transmission for kâˆˆâ„’Â¯ğ‘˜Â¯â„’k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}, the noisy model parameters at the PS and the clients are respectively given by

Client::Clientabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{Client:}\hskip 10.0pt ğœ½~k=ğœ½~+Î”â€‹ğœ½~k,kâˆˆâ„’Â¯,formulae-sequencesubscript~ğœ½ğ‘˜~ğœ½Î”subscript~ğœ½ğ‘˜ğ‘˜Â¯â„’\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}+\Delta\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k},k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}, (8a)

Let us first consider the loss function for active clients to solve (7a). III-B Communication Delay During Model Training

The bandwidth resources need to be optimized to reduce the latency of the transmission of both ğœ½ksubscriptğœ½ğ‘˜\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} (kâˆˆâ„’Â¯ğ‘˜Â¯â„’k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}) and ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} (kâˆˆâ„’ğ‘˜â„’k\in\mathcal{L}) to the PS during training. Let Ï„ksubscriptğœğ‘˜\tau_{k} be the communication time for the kğ‘˜kth client to transmit its either dataset (ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} for kâˆˆâ„’ğ‘˜â„’k\in\mathcal{L}) or model parameters (ğœ½ksubscriptğœ½ğ‘˜\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} for kâˆˆâ„’Â¯ğ‘˜Â¯â„’k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}). We define

Ï„k=dkRk,subscriptğœğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜\displaystyle\tau_{k}=\frac{d_{k}}{R_{k}}, (17)

where dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k} denotes the number of dataset symbols to transmit and Rk=Bkâ€‹lnâ¡(1+SNRk)subscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜subscriptğµğ‘˜1subscriptSNRğ‘˜R_{k}=B_{k}\ln(1+\textsf{SNR}_{k}) is the achievable transmission rate. Herein, Bksubscriptğµğ‘˜B_{k} and SNRksubscriptSNRğ‘˜\textsf{SNR}_{k} denote the allocated bandwidth and the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for the kğ‘˜kth client, respectively. The PS solves minBkâ¡maxkâˆˆğ’¦â¡Ï„ksubscriptsubscriptğµğ‘˜subscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğœğ‘˜\min_{B_{k}}\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\hskip 6.0pt\tau_{k} to optimize the bandwidth allocation by minimizing the maximum communication delay. This is because the model aggregation in the PS can be performed only after the completion of the slowest transmission for kâˆˆğ’¦ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\mathcal{K}. Although Rksubscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜R_{k} can vary for kâˆˆğ’¦ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\mathcal{K}, dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k} differentiates more significantly than Rksubscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜R_{k} between the inactive (i.e., kâˆˆâ„’ğ‘˜â„’k\in\mathcal{L}) and active (i.e., kâˆˆâ„’Â¯ğ‘˜Â¯â„’k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}) clientsÂ [36, 37]. Especially, depending on the client type, dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k} can be given by

dk={P,kâˆˆâ„’Â¯dk,kâˆˆâ„’,subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜casesğ‘ƒğ‘˜Â¯â„’subscriptdğ‘˜ğ‘˜â„’\displaystyle d_{k}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}P,&k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}\\ \textsf{d}_{k},&k\in\mathcal{L}\end{array}\right., (20)

which is fixed to the number of model parameters Pğ‘ƒP for the active clients, and to dk=Dkâ€‹(Uxâ€‹Vx+Uyâ€‹Vy)subscriptdğ‘˜subscriptğ·ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¥subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¦\textsf{d}_{k}=D_{k}(U_{x}V_{x}+U_{y}V_{y}) for Dksubscriptğ·ğ‘˜D_{k} input (âˆˆâ„UxÃ—Vxabsentsuperscriptâ„subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¥subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¥\in\mathbb{R}^{U_{x}\times V_{x}}) and output (âˆˆâ„UyÃ—Vyabsentsuperscriptâ„subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¦\in\mathbb{R}^{U_{y}\times V_{y}}) dataset samples.

Since the dataset size is usually larger than the number of model parameters in ML applications, i.e., dkâˆˆâ„’>Psubscriptdğ‘˜â„’ğ‘ƒ\textsf{d}_{k\in\mathcal{L}}>PÂ [19, 12, 11], the dataset transmission of the inactive clients is expected to take longer than the model transmission of the active clients, i.e., Ï„kâˆˆâ„’>Ï„kâˆˆâ„’Â¯subscriptğœğ‘˜â„’subscriptğœğ‘˜Â¯â„’\tau_{k\in\mathcal{L}}>\tau_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}}Â [36]. Previous FL-based works reported that Ï„kâˆˆâ„’subscriptğœğ‘˜â„’\tau_{k\in\mathcal{L}} can be approximately 101010 times longer than Ï„kâˆˆâ„’Â¯subscriptğœğ‘˜Â¯â„’\tau_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}}Â [20, 19]. This introduces a significant delay especially at the beginning of the training since the HFCL problem in (15b) or (16b) can be performed only if ğ’Ÿkâˆˆâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜â„’\mathcal{D}_{k\in\mathcal{L}} is collected at the PS for the first iteration. To tackle this issue and keep the training continuing, in the following, we propose two approaches, namely, ICpC and SDT in SectionÂ IV and V, respectively. Both of these techniques are applied only at the beginning of the training to handle effectively the dataset transmission of the inactive clients.

IV HFCL With Increased Computation-per-Client

Prior to the model training, i.e., at t=0ğ‘¡0t=0, the active clients need to wait until the inactive clients complete the dataset transmission, during which the active clients perform only one model computation. In order to keep the active clients continue model computing during the data transmission of inactive clients, we propose the ICpC approach, wherein the active clients move forward computing local model updates, but do not send them to the PS until the dataset transmission of the inactive clients is completedÂ [15]. This approach improves the convergence rate and the learning performance due to the continuation of the model updates at the inactive clients as similar observations are also reported inÂ [15], in which FL-only training is presented.

The algorithmic steps of the HFCL-ICpC approach are presented in AlgorithmÂ 1, for which the inputs are the datasets ğ’Ÿkâˆˆğ’¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ’¦\mathcal{D}_{k\in\mathcal{K}} and the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta. Different from HFCL, HFCL-ICpC involves with the model updates at the active clients during first communication round, i.e., t=0ğ‘¡0t=0, as in the lines 6âˆ’9696-9 of AlgorithmÂ 1. Using (17) and (20), and defining Qğ‘„Q as the block size, the active clients can perform N=maxkâˆˆâ„’â¡dkQğ‘subscriptğ‘˜â„’subscriptdğ‘˜ğ‘„N=\frac{\max_{k\in\mathcal{L}}\textsf{d}_{k}}{Q} iterations when t=0ğ‘¡0t=0 until the dataset transmission of the inactive clients is completed (Line 101010 of AlgorithmÂ 1). Although this method keeps the active clients busy with model computation instead of staying idle, it does not reduce the communication latency at the first iteration. As a result, the active clients perform Nğ‘N local updates, which improve the convergence rate from Oâ€‹(1t)ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡O(\frac{1}{t}) to Oâ€‹(N2t)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2ğ‘¡O(\frac{N^{2}}{t}) as compared to HFCLÂ [32].

V HFCL With Sequential Data Transmission

Compared to HFCL and HFCL-ICpC, wherein the first communication round awaits for the completion of the transmission of inactive clientsâ€™ datasets ğ’Ÿkâˆˆâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜â„’\mathcal{D}_{k\in\mathcal{L}}, HFCL-SDT involves with the transmission of smaller blocks of datasets. Hence, the data transmission time per communication round is smaller while the total amount of time to transmit ğ’Ÿkâˆˆâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜â„’\mathcal{D}_{k\in\mathcal{L}} to the PS is the same as in HFCL and HFCL-ICpC.

The algorithmic steps of the HFCL-SDT approach are given in AlgorithmÂ 1. Let Qğ‘„Q be the block size of each portion. as given in lines 6âˆ’146146-14 of AlgorithmÂ 1. The size of the training dataset, collected at the PS (i.e., tâ€‹Qğ‘¡ğ‘„tQ) for â„±kâ€‹(ğœ½k(t))subscriptâ„±ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}), becomes larger as tâ†’Nâ†’ğ‘¡ğ‘t\rightarrow N, and becomes equal to Dksubscriptğ·ğ‘˜D_{k} when t=Nğ‘¡ğ‘t=N. When t>Nğ‘¡ğ‘t>N, â„±kâ€‹(ğœ½k(t))subscriptâ„±ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}) is computed for the whole dataset of inactive clients for kâˆˆâ„’ğ‘˜â„’k\in\mathcal{L}, as in the 111111th step of AlgorithmÂ 1. While the size of the transmitted data from the inactive clients changes, the size of the transmitted information is fixed as Pğ‘ƒP for the active clients. This approach not only reduces the latency of the inactive clients, but also improves the learning accuracy as compared to HFCL since the features in the data are quickly learned at the PS due to the use of smaller datasets at the beginning. As a result, the model parameters corresponding to the inactive clients are computed in a mini-batch learning way, in which the dataset is partitioned into mini-batches of size Qğ‘„Q. Thus, the convergence rate of the inactive clients in HFCL-SDT is Oâ€‹(1Qâ€‹t+1t)ğ‘‚1ğ‘„ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡O(\frac{1}{\sqrt{Qt}}+\frac{1}{t}) while the rate of active clients is Oâ€‹(1t)ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡O(\frac{1}{t})Â [38].

VI Complexity Analysis and Communication Overhead

In this section, we investigate the efficiency of the proposed HFCL framework in terms of complexity and communication overhead.

VI-A Complexity Analysis

The complexity of the learning schemes, i.e., CL, FL and HFCL, can be analyzed in terms of convergence speed since the computation of the model parameters is done by solving the optimization problems (II-A), (4) and (16) via GD during trainingÂ [39, 17, 31]. Specifically, solving the optimization problems (II-A), (4) and (16) for in CL, FL and HFCL, respectively, yields the same convergence rate of Oâ€‹(1/t)ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡O(1/t) although the accuracy of these algorithms differ depending on the noise corruption (Ïƒ~2superscript~ğœ2\tilde{\sigma}^{2} and Ïƒk2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜2\sigma_{k}^{2}) on the model parametersÂ [17]. In particular, CL has higher learning accuracy than FL and HFCL since the model parameters are noise-free in CL while the accuracy of HFCL is between CL and FL since only a part of the model parameters (of inactive clients) are noise-free (see, e.g., Fig.Â 5). Furthermore, the convergence rates of the proposed HFCL techniques, HFCL-ICpC and HFCL-SDT, are different from those of CL, FL and HFCL since they involve the participation of both active and inactive clients during training. In HFCL-ICpC, the convergence rate of solving the optimization problem for inactive clients is Oâ€‹(1t)ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡O(\frac{1}{t}) while it is Oâ€‹(N2t)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2ğ‘¡O(\frac{N^{2}}{t}) for the active clients due to performing Nğ‘N local updates per iterationÂ [15]. As a result, the convergence is faster in active clients as compared to the inactive ones. Also in HFCL-SDT, the convergence rates of the active and inactive clients are Oâ€‹(1t)ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡O(\frac{1}{t}) and Oâ€‹(1Qâ€‹t+1t)ğ‘‚1ğ‘„ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡O(\frac{1}{\sqrt{Qt}}+\frac{1}{t}), respectively, due to the dataset is partitioned into Qğ‘„Q mini-batches in inactive clientsÂ [38]. Hence, one can conclude that the complexity of HFCL-ICpC is less than HFCL-SDT since the former reaches to convergence faster (see, e.g, Fig.Â 4). We summarize the convergence rates of the HFCL methods for both active and inactive clients in TableÂ III.

Next, we investigate the convergence of the proposed HFCL framework. In the literature, the convergence of the ML models has been studied for centralizedÂ [40] and federatedÂ [17, 31] schemes separately. In this paper, we analyze the convergence of the hybrid scenario, in which the convergence of the loss functions for active (â„±Â¯kâ€‹(ğœ½))subscriptÂ¯â„±ğ‘˜ğœ½(\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})) and inactive (â„±~kâ€‹(ğœ½)subscript~â„±ğ‘˜ğœ½\tilde{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})) clients in the presence of corrupted model parameters. First, similar to the previous studiesÂ [17, 31, 15], we make the following assumptions needed to ensure the convergence, which are typical for the Å‚2subscriptitalic-Å‚2\l_{2}-norm regularized linear regression, logistic regression, and softmax classifiers.

Assumption 1: The loss function â„±kâ€‹(ğœ½)subscriptâ„±ğ‘˜ğœ½\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is convex, i.e., â„±kâ€‹((1âˆ’Î»)â€‹ğœ½+Î»â€‹ğœ½â€²)â‰¤(1âˆ’Î»)â€‹ğœ½â€‹â„±kâ€‹(ğœ½)+Î»â€‹â„±kâ€‹(ğœ½â€²)subscriptâ„±ğ‘˜1ğœ†ğœ½ğœ†superscriptğœ½â€²1ğœ†ğœ½subscriptâ„±ğ‘˜ğœ½ğœ†subscriptâ„±ğ‘˜superscriptğœ½â€²\mathcal{F}_{k}((1-\lambda)\boldsymbol{\theta}+\lambda\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\leq(1-\lambda)\boldsymbol{\theta}\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\lambda\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}) for Î»âˆˆ[0,1]ğœ†01\lambda\in[0,1] and arbitrary ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta} and ğœ½â€²superscriptğœ½â€²\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}.

VI-B Communication Overhead

The communication overhead is due to the transmission of the dataset or the model parameters that are exchanged between the clients and the PS, wherein several signal processing techniques, such as channel acquisition, quantization, and resource allocation, are employed. Hence, the communication overhead can be measured by the number of transmitted symbols during model trainingÂ [19, 12, 7, 20]. Regarding the communication overhead of CL (ğ’¯CLsubscriptğ’¯CL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{CL}}), it can be given by the number of symbols used to transmit datasets while the overhead during FL (ğ’¯FLsubscriptğ’¯FL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{FL}}) is proportional to the number of communication rounds Tğ‘‡T and model parameters Pğ‘ƒP. Let D=âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦dkDsubscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptdğ‘˜{\textsf{D}}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{\textsf{d}}_{k} be the number of symbols of the whole dataset, then the communication overhead of CL, FL and HFCL are given respectively as

ğ’¯CLsubscriptğ’¯CL\displaystyle\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{CL}} =D,absentD\displaystyle={\textsf{D}}, (26)
ğ’¯FLsubscriptğ’¯FL\displaystyle\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{FL}} =2â€‹Tâ€‹Pâ€‹K,absent2ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ¾\displaystyle=2TPK, (27)
ğ’¯HFCLsubscriptğ’¯HFCL\displaystyle\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{HFCL}} =Lâ€‹dkâˆˆâ„’+2â€‹Tâ€‹Pâ€‹(Kâˆ’L),absentğ¿subscriptdğ‘˜â„’2ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ¾ğ¿\displaystyle=L{\textsf{d}}_{k\in\mathcal{L}}+2TP(K-L), (28)

where ğ’¯HFCLsubscriptğ’¯HFCL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{HFCL}} includes the transmission of the dataset from Lğ¿L inactive clients and the model parameters from Kâˆ’Lğ¾ğ¿K-L active clients. It is reasonable to assume that the size of the datasets is larger than the size of the model parameters, i.e., ğ’¯FLâ‰¤ğ’¯CLsubscriptğ’¯FLsubscriptğ’¯CL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{FL}}\leq\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{CL}}Â [19, 12, 7, 20, 11], which gives ğ’¯FLâ‰¤ğ’¯HFCLâ‰¤ğ’¯CLsubscriptğ’¯FLsubscriptğ’¯HFCLsubscriptğ’¯CL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{FL}}\leq\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{HFCL}}\leq\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{CL}}. Notice that the communication overhead is equal for all HFCL techniques proposed in this work, since they all involve the same amount of dataset and model transmission.

VII Numerical Simulations

In this section, we present the performance of the proposed HFCL frameworks in comparison to traditional CL- and FL-based training. We evaluate the performance on two datasets: i) image classification on the MNIST datasetÂ [41] and ii) 3D object detection on the Lyft Level 5 AV datasetÂ [42].

VII-A Image Classification

We evaluate the performance on the MNIST datasetÂ [41] including 28Ã—28282828\times 28 gray-scale images of handwritten digits with 101010 classes. The number of symbols on the whole dataset is D=282â‹…60,000â‰ˆ47Ã—106formulae-sequenceDâ‹…superscript2826000047superscript106{\textsf{D}}=28^{2}\cdot 60,000\approx 47\times 10^{6}. During model training, the dataset is partitioned into K=10ğ¾10K=10 blocks, each of which is available at the clients with identically independent distribution. Further, we train a CNN with 666 layers. The first layer is 28Ã—28282828\times 28 input layer. The second and the fourth layers are convolutional layers with 5Ã—5555\times 5@128128128 and 3Ã—3333\times 3@128128128 spatial filters, respectively. After each convolutional layer, there is a ReLUReLU\mathrm{ReLU} layer, which operates maxâ€‹(0,x)max0ğ‘¥\mathrm{max}(0,x) for its input xğ‘¥x. The output layer is a classification layer, which computes the probability distribution of the input data for 101010 classes. Thus, we have P=128â‹…(52+32)=4,352formulae-sequenceğ‘ƒâ‹…128superscript52superscript324352P=128\cdot(5^{2}+3^{2})=4,352 learnable parameters. The validation data of the MNIST dataset include 10,0001000010,000 images. The learning rate is selected as 0.0010.0010.001, which is reduced by half after each 303030 iterations, and the mini-batch size is selected as 128128128 for CL. Fig.Â 2 shows the communication overhead of CL, FL, and HFCL for L={0,1,3,5,7,10}ğ¿0135710L=\{0,1,3,5,7,10\}. During model training, we assume that 100010001000 data symbols are transmitted at each transmission block. Thus, it takes approximately 47Ã—10347superscript10347\times 10^{3} transmission blocks to complete CL-based training, while FL demands approximately 8,5Ã—10385superscript1038,5\times 10^{3} data blocks, which are approximately 666 times lower than that of CL. The communication overhead of HFCL (as well as HFCL-SDT and HFCL-ICpC) is between CL and FL since it depends on the number of inactive clients Lğ¿L and approaches to ğ’¯CLsubscriptğ’¯CL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{CL}} as Lâ†’Kâ†’ğ¿ğ¾L\rightarrow K.

To explicitly present the overhead for the hybrid frameworks, the number of transmitted symbols before (t=0ğ‘¡0t=0) and during (t>0ğ‘¡0t>0) training is presented in Fig.Â 3. Specifically, the whole communication overhead of CL is at t=0ğ‘¡0t=0 before training due the dataset transmission. In contrast, the overhead of FL is observed during training since no dataset transmission is involved, yet model transmission is taken place when t>0ğ‘¡0t>0. For the HFCL algorithms, they involve communication overheads before and during training since they involve both dataset and model transmission. Also, it is clear that the overhead of all hybrid frameworks are the same because they all involve the same amount of dataset and model transmission. However, they are distinguished in terms of the number of symbols transmitted before and during training. While HFCL and HFCL-ICpC have the same amount of overhead during training, HFCL-SDT has a lower overhead before training due to transmitting the datasets sequentially. Furthermore, we see that the overhead of FL is twice the amount during training for HFCL and HFCL-ICpC. This is because L=5ğ¿5L=5 for HFCL and HFCL-ICpC, and L=K=10ğ¿ğ¾10L=K=10 for FL. While the overhead of FL may seem lower compared to our HFCL frameworks, the former does not work if the clients have no capability for model computation, which is taken into account in the latter frameworks at the cost of a moderate increase in the overhead.

In Fig.Â 4, we present the training performance of the competing methods for L=5ğ¿5L=5, SNRğœ½=20subscriptSNRğœ½20\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=20 dB, and B=5ğµ5B=5 quantization bits with respect to number of communication rounds. Note that we assume the dataset transmission is completed in CL prior to the training, and the completion of each communication round in FL corresponds to each iteration in CL. HFCL-ICpC has a higher accuracy at the beginning of the training due to multiple updates at the active clients, and it keeps outperforming HFCL and HFCL-SDT for the remaining iterations. Thanks to STD, HFCL-SDT also has higher performance than HFCL, which performs better than conventional FL. Notice that all the proposed HFCL approaches have moderate performance between FL and CL, as theoretically proved in SectionÂ VI. We note that the performance of FL is computed by assuming that all Kğ¾K clients participate in training, which is not possible if there exist inactive clients, for which FL is not the applicable training framework.

Fig.Â 5 shows the classification accuracy with respect to the number of inactive clients Lğ¿L when SNRğœ½=20subscriptSNRğœ½20\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=20 dB. The proposed HFCL approaches perform better than FL for 0<L<K0ğ¿ğ¾0<L<K since, in FL, the collected models from the active clients are corrupted by the wireless channel whose effects reduce as Lâ†’Kâ†’ğ¿ğ¾L\rightarrow K. When L=0ğ¿0L=0, HFCL, HFCL-SDT, and HFCL-ICpC are identical to FL since all the clients are active whereas they perform the same as CL if L=K=10ğ¿ğ¾10L=K=10 since all the clients are inactive, i.e., they transmit their datasets to the PS, and the noise-free model parameters can be used for model training. Comparing the HFCL algorithms, it yields that both HFCL-ICpC and HFCL-SDT provide higher accuracy than HFCL for 0<L<K0ğ¿ğ¾0<L<K. HFCL-ICpC starts the training process when t=0ğ‘¡0t=0 with locally-updated models at the active clients, thus, it provides a higher accuracy than both HFCL and HFCL-SDT. Also, HFCL-SDT starts the training with the same conditions as in HFCL while HFCL-SDT incorporates smaller datasets at the beginning for t<Nğ‘¡ğ‘t<N. Thus, higher accuracy levels are reached quicker than HFCL, which computes the model parameters on the whole local dataset of the inactive clients for t<Nğ‘¡ğ‘t<N, leading to a slower convergence rate.

In Fig.Â 5, we also present the performance of FL with only LÂ¯Â¯ğ¿\bar{L} active clients where LÂ¯=Kâˆ’LÂ¯ğ¿ğ¾ğ¿\bar{L}=K-L is the number of active clients. That is to say, the learning model is trained on only the dataset of active clients, whereas it is tested on the whole dataset. We also consider the scenario that the training is conducted by only LÂ¯âˆ’2Â¯ğ¿2\bar{L}-2 active clients, two of which do not participate into the training due to the privacy concerns or limited conditions, such as having very low channel gainÂ [33, 43]. We observe that FL becomes unable to learn the data as Lğ¿L increases since the training is conducted only on the datasets of active clients. This shows the effectiveness of the proposed HFCL approach, in which all of the clients participate in the learning stage. It is worthwhile to note that when L=K=10ğ¿ğ¾10L=K=10, there will be no active clients, hence FL will not be performed. The performance loss can be severe as Lâ†’Kâ†’ğ¿ğ¾L\rightarrow K due to the absence of inactive clientsâ€™ datasets if the dataset is non-identically distributed because the active clients cannot learn the whole features in the dataset of other devices.

We further present the classification performance with respect to the noise corruption on the model parameters for both identically independent distribution (IID) and non-IID cases in Fig.Â 6a and Fig.Â 6b, respectively. In IID scenario, the dataset is uniform randomly shuffled over the clients while for non-IID case, the dataset is sorted by labels and each client is then randomly assigned with 1 or 2 labelsÂ [15, 35]. We compare the classification accuracy of the proposed HFCL methods with existing advanced FL techniques, i.e., FedAvgÂ [15] and FedProxÂ [44]. Specifically, in FedAvg, all the clients apply Nğ‘N local model updates in each communication round whereas N=1ğ‘1N=1 in conventional FL. Also, the clients employ different number of local model updates in FedProx (i.e., variable Nğ‘N)Â [44]. We set SNRğœ½subscriptSNRğœ½\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} as SNRğœ½=[0,20]subscriptSNRğœ½020\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=[0,20] dB and SNRğœ½=SNRğ’ŸsubscriptSNRğœ½subscriptSNRğ’Ÿ\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\mathrm{SNR}_{\mathcal{D}}, which is defined as the SNR of the noise added onto the transmitted datasets. We can see from Fig.Â 6 that the FL-based methods (e.g., FedAvg, FedProx and FL) are exposed to approximately 4.5%percent4.54.5\% loss in the learning accuracy while the HFCL methods perform 3.5%percent3.53.5\% poorer due to non-IID datasets. The slight performance improvement of HFCL methods can be attributed to the computation of model parameters at the PS. Furthermore, we observe that FedAvg has superior performance than FL due to multiple local model updates while FedProx performs better due to performing different number of local updates. Nevertheless, the proposed HFCL techniques have higher accuracy due to the computation of the model updates (of inactive clients) in the PS. As expected, compared to the FL-based methods and the proposed hybrid algorithms, CL is more robust against noise because its model parameters are not corrupted by wireless transmission since they are computed at the PS. Comparing the effect of noise in datasets and model parameters, it can be concluded that the learning accuracy depends more on the corruptions in the model than the datasets. This is because the noise in the model makes it unable to learn the data while the noise in the dataset is, to some extend, helpful to make the model robust against the imperfections in the data. Therefore, artificial noise is usually added onto the dataset in many applications, such as image classificationÂ [2, 3], and physical layer design in wireless communicationsÂ [20, 25].

In Fig.Â 7, we present the classification accuracy with respect to the quantization level of the model parameters for Bâˆˆ[1,8]ğµ18B\in[1,8] when SNRğœ½=20subscriptSNRğœ½20\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=20 dB. Note that the quantization is only applied to wireless-transmitted models, i.e., FL, FedAvg, FedProx and HFCL. Hence, the performance of CL does not change. The model parameters are quantized layer by layer between the maximum and minimum weights of each layerÂ [14]. As expected, the classification accuracy improves as BğµB increases due to the enhancement of the model precision. We can conclude that at least a 555-bit quantization is required for a reliable classification accuracy.

VII-B 3D Object Detection

We evaluate the performance of the HFCL framework on the 3D object detection problem in vehicular networks, based on the Lyft Level 5 AV datasetÂ [42], collected from lidar and cameras mounted on vehiclesÂ [6]. The input data are selected as a top view image of the ego vehicle, which includes the received lidar signal strengths for different elevations, as shown in Fig.Â 8a. The output data are the classified representation of the vehicles/objects as boxes, which are obtained by the preprocessing of the images from the cameras, as illustrated in Fig.Â 8aÂ 555While we assumed that the dataset is labeled, the annotation of the objects in the data samples is an important task, for which the reader can refer toÂ [6, 7].. The training dataset is collected from 101010 vehicles in different areas after preprocessing of the camera and lidar data. We assume that L=3ğ¿3L=3 of the vehicles are inactive while the remaining ones are active clients. Each dataset includes 103superscript10310^{3} input-output pairs, whose sizes are 336Ã—336Ã—33363363336\times 336\times 3 and 336Ã—336Ã—13363361336\times 336\times 1, respectively. Hence, the total number of data symbols are (336Ã—336Ã—3+336Ã—336)Ã—104â‰ˆ4.5Ã—1093363363336336superscript1044.5superscript109(336\times 336\times 3+336\times 336)\times 10^{4}\approx 4.5\times 10^{9}. The dataset has 999 classes, i.e., carcar\mathrm{car}, motorcyclemotorcycle\mathrm{motorcycle}, busbus\mathrm{bus}, bicyclebicycle\mathrm{bicycle}, trucktruck\mathrm{truck}, pedestrianpedestrian\mathrm{pedestrian}, otherâ€‹vehicleothervehicle\mathrm{other}\hskip 2.0pt\mathrm{vehicle}, animalanimal\mathrm{animal}, and emergencyâ€‹vehicleemergencyvehicle\mathrm{emergency}\hskip 2.0pt\mathrm{vehicle}, which are represented by the boxes as shown in Fig.Â 8a. We have used the U-netÂ [45] with 888 convolutional layers to learn the features in the input data and achieve 3D object detection and segmentation. The total number of parameters in U-net is approximately 2Ã—1062superscript1062\times 10^{6}, and the training is conducted for T=40ğ‘‡40T=40 communication rounds.

The training performance of the competing methods is presented in Fig.Â 8b, from which we obtain similar observations as in the image classification scenario in the previous part. HFCL methods provide a moderate performance between CL and FL. Nevertheless, all of the vehicles can participate in training while the conventional FL methods cannot support it and the communication overhead of CL is prohibitive. Thus, HFCL provides a solution for the the trade-off between the computational capabilities of the clients and the communication overhead.

In Fig.8c, the numbers of transmitted data symbols for CL, FL and HFCL are presented. The overhead of CL is due to the transmission of whole data symbols, i.e., approximately 4.5Ã—1094.5superscript1094.5\times 10^{9}. In contrast, the complexity of FL is due to the two way (edge â‡†â‡†\leftrightarrows server) transmission of the model updates during training until convergence, i.e., 2Ã—40Ã—(2Ã—106)=160Ã—1062402superscript106160superscript1062\times 40\times(2\times 10^{6})=160\times 10^{6} for 404040 iterations. As a result, FL and HFCL have approximately 282828 and 333 times lower communication overhead compared to CL, respectively. The effectiveness of HFCL in terms of overhead is reduced compared to the image classification application because of the larger input size of the object detection problem (i.e., 336Ã—336Ã—33363363336\times 336\times 3 versus 28Ã—28Ã—12828128\times 28\times 1).

VIII Summary

In this paper, we introduced a hybrid federated and centralized learning (HFCL) approach for distributed ML tasks. The proposed approach is helpful if a portion of the edge devices do not have the computational capability for model computation during training, which is quite common in practice. In order to train the learning model collaboratively, only the active devices, which have sufficient computational capability, perform FL by computing the model updates on their local datasets whereas the remaining inactive devices, which do not have enough computational power, resort to CL and send their local datasets to the PS, which performs the model computation on behalf of them. As a result, HFCL provides a novel solution achieving a trade-off between FL and CL in terms of computation capability of edge devices and communication overhead. Moreover, the transmission of local datasets may generate delays during training if the dataset size of the inactive clients is large. We suggested a mitigation of this problem by proposing HFCL-ICpC and HFCL-SDT frameworks. While the former improves the learning accuracy with a model computation-per-client, the latter reduces the size of the transmitted datasets. Compared to CL, the proposed approach is more advantageous due to the reduction in the communication latency. In the meantime, compared to FL, a drawback of the proposed HFCL approach is that HFCL requires the dataset transmission of the inactive clients, which may raise privacy concerns, however, these are already apparent in CL. Nevertheless, HFCL provides access to the dataset of all devices regardless of their computational capability whereas, in FL, only the dataset of the inactive clients could be used. We showed that our HFCL approach has a significant performance improvement as compared to FL-based training with only active clients since FL cannot access the dataset of all clients. As a future work, we plan to study the application of HFCL to physical layer applications, such as channel estimation, resource allocation, and beamforming. Furthermore, the noisy learning model may not represent the practical case, hence requires further research on realistic modeling.
